dt.t: … he had been betrayed into a position which neither {wi}contented{/wi} his heart nor satisfied his conscience.

dt: {bc}to limit (oneself) in requirements, desires, or actions

dt.t: The rainy weather spoiled our plans for the beach, so we had to {wi}content{/wi} ourselves with a relaxing day at home.

et: Middle English {it}contenten{/it} "to rest satisfied, satisfy," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}contenter{/it} "to satisfy," borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}contentāre,{/it} verbal derivative of Latin {it}contentus{/it} "satisfied" {ma}{mat|content:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: to limit (oneself) in requirements, desires, or actions

dt: {bc}the topics or matter treated in a written work
{bc}the principal substance (such as written matter, illustrations, or music) offered by a website

dt.t: … Internet users have evolved an ethos of free {wi}content{/wi} in the Internet.

dt: {bc}the events, physical detail, and information in a work of art {dx}compare {dxt|form||10c}{/dx}

dt.t: The film was rated R for its violent {wi}content{/wi}.

dt: {bc}the matter dealt with in a field of study
{bc}a part, element, or complex of parts

et: Middle English, borrowed from Anglo-French & Medieval Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}contentum{/it} (usually in plural {it}contenta{/it}), noun derivative from neuter past participle of Latin {it}continēre{/it} "to hold together, restrain, have as contents" {ma}{mat|contain|}{/ma}
shortdef: the topics or matter treated in a written work
the principal substance (such as written matter, illustrations, or music) offered by a website
